Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Ammonia (NH3) Emission from Fertilizer Application: Understanding an Uncertain Input to Air Quality Models
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project will measure ammonia emissions from the corn plot at the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign (UIUC) Energy Farm and to scale local emissions to the regional scale. The ammonia emissions will be measured by relaxed eddy accumulation and the aerodynamic gradient method using denuders and a cavity ringdown spectrometer, respectively. Emissions above and within the corn canopy at the landscape scale will be interpreted with a bi-directional exchange model. A process-scale modeling approach using EPIC (Erosion Productivity Impact Calculator) and its interactive version (i-EPIC), which are driven by environmental factors regulating ammonia emissions (i.e., meteorology, soil and canopy characteristics, land use, and mass of fertilizer applied), will be used to scale local emissions to the regional scale.

The results of the project will be disseminated through the venues of research conferences and publications but also through the use of web-based tools. The principal investigators will interact with the National Atmospheric Deposition Program (NADP) to examine the potential of integration with the existing pilot Ammonia Monitoring Network and with the NADP's Critical Loads and Total Deposition Science subcommittees. As part of the educational and mentoring component, undergraduate students will be recruited, with specific emphasis on underrepresented groups, and mentored by the principal investigators and graduate students, on the research methods of this project. They will also be mentored on preparing presentation material for professional conferences and for transferring their knowledge to high school age female students from diverse backgrounds participating with STEM campus activities. As part of this research project, new teaching modules will be developed for air quality courses with focus on atmospheric deposition models and use of micrometeorological methods. Teaching modules will also be developed for a new summer camp focused on environmental engineering, for high school age female students. The additional teaching modules related to the topic of this proposal will focus on the effects of food and biofuel production on air quality and climate change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the US, nitrogen-based fertilizers improve agricultural crop yields. However, emission of ammonia from fertilized cropland results in adverse environmental effects with damages estimated at $100 billion annually. The goals of the project were to: a) measure ammonia emissions from fertilizer application at the local scale in an intensively managed agro-ecosystem; and b) develop a method to connect ammonia emissions at the local scale with the regional scale. These goals were motivated by the importance of ammonia impacts on air and water quality and ecosystems.

Ammonia reacts in the atmosphere with other gases to form tiny particles. These particles penetrate deep into the lungs and cause chronic serious health effects. Lack of accurate information on magnitude and timing of ammonia emissions interferes with the ability of air quality models to accurately predict concentrations of these tiny particles in the atmosphere. Despite this need and the fact that nitrogen fertilized agricultural areas are important sources of atmospheric ammonia, there are very few measurements in the US to provide accurate information on ammonia peak emissions and timing. Because it is expensive and impractical to measure everywhere, it is important to have computer models that can predict ammonia emissions everywhere. However, to develop such reliable tools and be able to evaluate them, measurements are necessary. Therefore, the two goals of the project are interlinked.

Ammonia is hard to measure, first because it is very reactive, second because its concentrations in the atmosphere are very small. Sampling for ammonia needs detailed protocols and procedures not to contaminate the samples or introduce artifacts. Indirect methods that measure ammonia concentrations in atmospheric updrafts and downdrafts or at two or more heights are preferred because they do not disturb the environment that is sampled. However, because such measurements depend on atmospheric conditions at a given location and time, there is need to understand how these methods perform at different conditions and develop benchmarks for their performance. The measurement methods used in this project are called relaxed eddy accumulation and flux gradient.

The measurements were used to evaluate computer models that simulate the effects of weather conditions, farm management practices (such as crop grown, fertilizer application rate and depth, tilling, irrigation), soil properties and chemical reactions in soil to predict ammonia emissions from cropland to the atmosphere. The premise is that if predictions of the models agree with measurements at the few locations where there are measurements, then we have confidence in using the models to obtain estimates of magnitude and timing of ammonia emissions in other locations, as well. Subsequently, we combined results from these models with a Geographical Information System database we developed to estimate location and timing of ammonia emissions over the continental US. The database includes high resolution crop maps, state-level crop nitrogen demand, crop schedules, soil properties, climate parameters and county-level fertilizer sales data.

Analysis of measurement and modeling results showed that a) the two measurement methods were in agreement about the timing of peak ammonia emissions and the total ammonia released during a full corn growing season, at the measurement location in Midwest US; b) predictions from the computer models were in close agreement with measurement data; c) comparison with computer model results supports that urease inhibitor delayed and reduced the amount of ammonia emissions; d) using updated ammonia emissions as input to an air quality model showed that ammonia emissions from fertilizer application impact the distribution of tiny particle pollution in the US Midwest region, where chemical fertilizer application is the major source of atmospheric ammonia.

This project has impacts beyond the scientific community. Ammonia loss from fertilized cropland represents an economic loss for farmers. In addition, ammonia along with other nitrogen compounds in the atmosphere can fall back to cropland and alter the structure and diversity of plants, degrade surface water quality, and change soil chemistry. Knowing how much ammonia is emitted from agricultural fields receiving nitrogen fertilizers can help predict its impact on air quality, water quality and ecosystem health. Understanding what processes control the release of ammonia can help identify practices that result in reduced ammonia losses for the benefit of farmer income and for the protection of health and the environment.

This project further contributes to a) better understanding of the measurements methods used; b) a database of measured ammonia fluxes from fertilizer application during a full corn growing season in the Midwest US, (filling a gap in information needed for air quality, atmospheric deposition and N fertilizer application rate and efficiency studies); c) training and education of postdoctoral (1), graduate (8) and undergraduate research assistants (7); d) education of college students who take classes that include new modules on the measurement methods and the nitrogen cycle; and e) (K-12) lessons for outreach to students from underrepresented groups.
